qas.question: What order of magnitude of capacitance is suitable for capacitors comprised of ceramic disks with metallic coatings?
How are larger value capacitors often constructed?

answers.text: multiple stacks of plates and disks

qas.question: What do larger value capacitors often use as the dielectric medium?

answers.text: impregnated paper or plastic – these are rolled up to save space

qas.question: Why are the plates and dielectrics often staggered in larger value capacitors?

answers.text: To reduce the series resistance and inductance

qas.question: How are the conductive plates often made for larger value capacitors?

answers.text: metal film layer deposited on the surface of a dielectric film

qas.question: What order of magnitude of capacitance is suitable for capacitors comprised of ceramic disks without metallic coatings?

plausible_answers.text: multiple stacks of plates and disks

qas.question: How are smaller value capacitors often constructed?
What do smaller value capacitors often use as the dielectric medium?

plausible_answers.text: To reduce the series resistance and inductance for long plates

qas.question: Why are the plates and dielectrics often staggered in smaller value capacitors?

plausible_answers.text: metal film layer deposited on the surface of a dielectric film

qas.question: How are the conductive plates never made for larger value capacitors?

context: The arrangement of plates and dielectric has many variations depending on the desired ratings of the capacitor. For small values of capacitance (<a0_0><b5_0>microfarads and less<b5_0/><a0_0/>), ceramic disks use metallic coatings, with wire leads bonded to the coating. Larger values can be made by <a1_0><b6_0>multiple stacks of plates and disks<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Larger value capacitors usually use a metal foil or <a4_0><b9_0>metal film layer deposited on the surface of a dielectric film<b9_0/><a4_0/> to make the plates, and a dielectric film of <a2_0><b7_0>impregnated paper or plastic<b7_0/> – these are rolled up to save space<a2_0/>. <a3_0><b8_0>To reduce the series resistance and inductance<a3_0/> for long plates<b8_0/>, the plates and dielectric are staggered so that connection is made at the common edge of the rolled-up plates, not at the ends of the foil or metalized film strips that comprise the plates.
